X. THE BALANCE SHEET

Earlier in this report it was stated that the decision to proceed with
an expressway must depend not only upon the general advantages of
expressways, but also upon the pros and cons of a specific route. Having
reached the conclusion that the Harbor Route is the best location for the
East-West Expressway it remains to balance the price of an expressway
along this route against the advantages to determine whether the East-
West Expressway should be built at all.

Price of an East-West Expressway along the Harbor Route

While no cost estimate has been made of an East-West Expressway
along the Harbor Route the bulk of the cost will be absorbed by the
Federal Government. The cost to the City will probably be in the range
of $20,000,000.

Taxable private property which would have to be acquired for right-
of-way purposes has a present assessed valuation of approximately $16,-
000,000. Assuming a tax rate of $3.50 the construction of the expressway
would produce an apparent loss of real estate taxes of $560,000 per year.
This would be reduced, however, by the extent to which property owners
invested the proceeds of sales in new construction within the City. Such
investment would certainly occur to some extent but it would be impos-
sible to predict the degree to which it might happen. In addition, studies
in other cities have indicated that expressways which are well located
usually increase substantially the value and the assessed valuation of
adjacent properties. Should this happen in Baltimore, and there is every
reason to expect that it would within the nonresidential areas adjacent to
the Harbor Route, the loss in assessed valuation might be largely or wholly
cancelled out.

The East-West Expressway along the Harbor Route would require
the demolition of a large number of buildings. The total number would

be 2705, of which 2020 are wholly residential and 685 are commercial,
industrial or mixed. However, most of the buildings are old and obsolete,
and many are dilapidated or slums. As noted in detail in the previous
chapter only a handful are of any significance.

As a matter of fact, not only would the clearance of many of the
buildings along the proposed route not harm the City, one can go further
and say that their removal would be advantageous. The blocks between
Mulberry and Franklin Streets running from Monroe Street to Fremont
Avenue are a good example. These blocks are a part of the Harlem Park
Urban Renewal Area and are earmarked in the Harlem Park Urban Re-
newal Plan for clearance for the East-West Expressway. If the City
should decide to abandon the expressway it is highly probable that the
Harlem Park Plan would continue to propose clearance for most of the
buildings in these blocks based upon their poor condition. The same
conclusion can be reached for most of the buildings along the Harbor
Route from Fremont Avenue to Light Street. All of these are within the
Downtown Renewal Area and if the East-West Expressway were given up
the applicable urban renewal plans would almost certainly involve the
clearance of most of these structures. In other words, wholly apart from
the expressway, the buildings along the proposed route all the way from
Monroe Street to Light Street are in such shape that a large measure of
clearance would be indicated in any event. This stretch includes two-
thirds of all of the buildings which would have to be cleared if the East-
West Expressway were built along the Harbor Route.

One other price would have to be paid—namely, a very large amount
of relocation both by families and by commercial firms. There is no point
in ignoring this problem, but it is fair to note that by proper planning it
can be spread over a number of years and that the Urban Renewal and
Housing Agency’s Relocation Service would be availgble to assist. In no
